misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the while loop condition (index == -1) is a 'daemon' or continuous monitor that will stop the loop's execution the very instant the variable 'index' is updated.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java Notional Machine, a loop condition is only evaluated at the start of each iteration. Any code remaining in the loop block (such as i++) will still execute to completion even if the condition becomes false mid-block.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: In this specific program, the error is latent and does not cause a bug because 'i' is not used after the loop. However, if the student tried to use 'i' as the result, it would be off-by-one (e.g., if the target was at index 1, 'i' would be 2 when the loop finishes).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the 'not found' result (-1) is a special symbolic message that must be handled as a literal string, rather than simply being the current state of the 'index' variable.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to recognize that the variable 'index' already holds the value -1 in the failure case. Instead of relying on the variable's value to drive the output, they branch logic to print a hardcoded string literal.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: This leads to redundant logic. Instead of a single print statement using the 'index' variable, the student creates an if-else structure to separate the literal '-1' from other numeric values.
